job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, well maintained, nice scenery
cons: We are treated as disposable. If we work above and beyond, that workload becomes the expectation without compensation. There is no growth structure for non-tenure track educators. We are used to keep the department's high enrollment lower division courses rolling, and forced to teach six sections of the same course in a quarter. Beware - it is a life-sucking dead end. Educators are better off teaching at a public university or a community college, feel good about the fact that they are helping students who don't have the option of $60K yearly tuition, and earn more doing it.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, start staff with 3 weeks vacation a year, great sick benefits. I used to love my job and was at SCU for 16 years.
cons: The pay scale is very low. At the beginning of the pandemic, SCU's administration cut their contribution to staff retirement accounts, stating that this was necessary due to projected loss of revenue because of covid. SCU actually increased their endowment substantially during this time, but never fully reinstated their former level of contribution to staff retirement accounts.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Lovely campus and some of my colleagues were very nice
cons:
Divisions among the law school faculty run deep, and there is little contact between the many “contract” faculty and the “tenure stream” or tenured faculty. For example, adjunct faculty in the law school are excluded from faculty meetings and from department meetings; they must learn about curricular changes, even those that effect the classes they are assigned to teach, third hand. This not only leads to isolation, but prevents the productive exchange of ideas and the comradery one might expect in a less stratified law school.

This stratification also shows itself in resource distribution – if an adjunct needs to have an unanticipated and confidential conversation with a student, he or she must hope to find a quiet corner. Adjuncts don’t get assigned office space of any kind.

In addition to these systemic exclusions, the disdain with which “lesser” faculty are sometimes treated can be frustrating and soul destroying. An email from an adjunct to a tenured member of the law faculty will, in my experience, be ignored. If it includes a question, it may be forwarded, without comment, to a different department in the law school. Perhaps most unfortunate from the point of view of student success, ideas from adjuncts may be ignored, even when the adjunct has considerable expertise in the subject area. For example, despite the recent, steady declines in bar passage rates at Santa Clara Law, the office tasked with bar preparation at Santa Clara Law advised me to take my extensive experience with bar tutoring to a law school that needed it – and even attached a list of California law schools.

After years of effort, adjuncts across Santa Clara University were able to unionize, despite fierce opposition from university elites. One comment from a tenured member of the faculty inadvertently pinpointed the fundamental problem the organizers sought to address. As preface to his lengthy remarks, this professor remarked that adjunct unionization efforts did not affect him since he was tenured.

It was a remarkable “let them eat cake” moment at an institution that prides itself on the pursuit of social justice.

review_title: Great Coworkers, not so great management
job_title: Student Caller in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The call center is a really fun place to work, and a great way to get to know other students while working a campus job. The experience gained through calling is very valuable, and the call center itself is a great team environment. For sure the most engaging on campus job. The call center also pays commission on donations, so there is monetary incentive to perform well. Despite the best efforts of the upper management, the students, supervisors, and director make the call center an enjoyable, lively, and social experience, encouraging a team mindset between employees, and incorporating fun games into the job.
cons: There is a lack of general transparency between the upper management and the callers. Everyone that we directly interface with is awesome, but management above the director of the call center is not very in-touch with the callers. I have been written up for unclear and unfair reasons, and had no option to dispute the write up, even though I tried. I know that I am not the only one who has dealt with this. The general feeling is that "the people upstairs" are kind of scary, and want to kill the fun and social part of the job. Between this and the sometimes random punitive action, the position of student caller feels awfully expendable, which is not very motivating or conducive to productivity. It seems like instead of changing the way things work at the call center to incorporate employee feedback, the university would rather hire a slew of new people to replace the ones who raise objections. That may contribute to the crazy high turnover rate. Generally, the big bosses in the fundraising department do not seem very interested in improving the call center. Things are very set in their ways, including unchanging scripts, and redundant, tedious training sessions. Communication around the pandemic was almost nonexistent, which was irritating, but unsurprising.

job_title: Lecturer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The warmth of students and their eager attitudes about learning at SCU is inspiring. It was a joy to engage in intellectual pursuits with all the fine young people who attend this school, whether they were part of my particular department or from the wider University. The SCU student is highly engaged and also seeks deeper values in life. My own intellectual knowledge increased and solidified while preparing and teaching courses over the years, but the emotional and spiritual depth of many students was what appealed to me the most. If you plan to be tenured, then this is a terrific place to hone your skills alongside great colleagues. Your salary will be decent and the rewards go far beyond money.
cons: Over the years I observed as a faculty member,  the middle and sometimes upper administration increased its involvement  regarding decisions on a departmental level.  The faculty and Chairs know far better how to steer the course of each department and what skills and courses are required to achieve a career in their particular fields. The continuing struggle between faculty and administration is both tiring and detrimental and not in the best interests of the students who are ultimately the customers.

review_title: Lovely place to work and teach.
job_title: Assistant Professor in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Beautiful campus.  Polite students.  Supportive faculty. Moderate support of research in terms of funds.  Close community.  If you are able to do some research, and not dedicate too much time to all of the possible service opportunities, you can have a nice work/life balance.  Family friendly university.
cons: No graduate students.  The university does not require, or reward, excellence.  Many very intelligent faculty have a great deal of time on their hands to be concerned with committees, faculty senate, and student evaluations of teaching.  This is fine, but there isn't always the social support to enable strong research because the culture demands a great deal of service.  Also, this salaries within the College of Arts and Sciences are low, especially considering the extremely high cost of living in the Silicon Valley right now.

job_title: Grader/Tutor in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Both jobs have flexible hours. You set your own schedule. There are bureaucratic rules about not working for too long or not working on certain days, but they are only enforced by the timesheet, so in practice you can work whenever you want to.
- Grading is work from home
- In general, a lot of freedom  in how your work
-  Very educational
cons:
For being a grader:
- Professors don't really have clear grading guidelines
- They only pay you for 3 hours even though realistically it takes longer
- Low pay. Near minimum wage

For being a tutor for Math Learning center:
- The calendar system is really annoying to interface with.

job_title: Information Specialist in Santa Clara, CA
pros: All the staff here are really friendly. It's amazing that some have worked here for 20+ years. It just goes to show that this is a great place to work at. There are special committees for everything if you want to get more involved. It's also a place where you can leave all your work at work and not have to worry about anything when you get home. I wouldn't say it's a stress free place to work, but the benefits of working here greatly outnumber the cons. Plus, free tuition for staff and their dependents!
cons: While working with some of the students, I feel that they feel that they are privileged because they attend SCU and demand special attention. I also don't feel that there is a lot of diversity on campus but it seems to be getting better.

review_title: Great Working Environment in Affluent Bubble
job_title: Quarterly Lecturer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Supportive colleagues; beautiful campus; tremendous opportunity for professional development through workshops, classes, etc. Generous support for academic research even for part-time faculty. Generous compensation for part-time faculty compared to other local institutions.
cons: No benefits for part-time faculty, even with extensive teaching loads, contrary to Jesuit social justice values. No job security or stability from quarter to quarter for most lecturers. Affluent bubble mentality makes most faculty and staff oblivious to real economic situations of part-time colleagues who teach for half full-time pay.

review_title: Santa Clara University was one of the best places to work for in Silicon Valley.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: My co-workers were friendly team players, with the same goal in mind in serving the students, faculty and staff to the best of their ability, and worked together to reach this common goal.
cons: The only con for me was having to resign and move to another state.  I am hoping to find the same workplace where I am living now.

job_title: in Santa Clara, CA
pros: There are some really great people working here. I worked in the housing department for two years. I can't say that I regret working here. I met a lot of interesting and fun people. Up until I left, I had a generally positive experience.
cons: Unfortunately, I had a negative experience that caused me to leave. I can honestly say both parties were at fault in some way. But what I was most disappointed in was the lack of leadership and decision making. People at the top, at least in housing, were extremely immature and led to many employees leaving prematurely.

review_title: Not quite the same warm & fuzzy place it was when I first started
job_title: Finance Professional in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
* Generally, most staff/faculty are very nice and approachable.
* It is small enough that you can be on a first name basis with a lot of people in different departments. 
* Good work/life balance.
cons:
* Pay is low
* Career growth/pay growth is non existent.
* Tend to hire from outside than give opportunities to staff within.

review_title: A great work place filled with compassionate individuals who care about their jobs.
job_title: Santa Clara Financial Aid Call Center in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The campus is a close-knit community full of friendly individuals. Occasional off campus get togethers for staff to bond and be rewarded for their hard work. Work life based on the core values of the university: competence, conscience, and compassion.
cons: Depending on what department you join upward mobility is limited. Working at Santa Clara University you will realize that the school is mainly focused on revenue, it is a business first and school second. Raises are capped at a standard increase per year based on whether or not specific criteria has been met rather than a review of merit.

review_title: School of Law - Academic and Professional Development
job_title: Program Coordinator in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Post-secondary environment, intellectually advanced company and friendly coworkers and immediate colleagues.  Chairs and 3rd floor couches on outside patio of the library make for lovely luncheon nap spots.  Gorgeous campus, stimulating events calendars, and flavorful, cheap, and student-free eats at the Adobe Lodge.
cons: The air of mystery and drawn-out tension that upper management employed to mask ongoing early retirement program restructuring options for numerous departmental staff and programs created an atmosphere of tension, suspicion, and resentment among staff, who felt as though they constantly had to defend their jobs and

review_title: Great Place To Work as Student
job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great Place to work as a student. Very flexible work schedule as well as time to do homework if needed. All of my co-workers were students and so it was a great community to be in.
cons: Being required to work during finals week sometimes can be hard but manageable. Sometimes you get inconsistency depending on who is your boss.

job_title: IT Staff in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Very innovative and engaged students and faculty
cons: IT people don't get to be much of a part of the University experience. Management keep us away from being directly involved in the work the University is pursuing

review_title: Great place to learn skills useful in future careers
job_title: Community Facilitator in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Free housing, develop as a leader, Meet a lot of people that have good work and study habits on campus.
cons: Social Sacrifice, Balancing school and work can be difficult for some, You're never "off the clock" so you have to be careful in the way you present yourself in classes and even off campus.

review_title: A Campus Mission Intern (engineer) feeling fulfilled!
job_title: Campus Ministry Intern in Santa Clara, CA
pros: To get an engineering degree at a school that strongly intertwines technical education with global perspective, social justice, and ethics is truly amazing. To work under professors that live by these codes is a double win. Particularly at campus ministry, they extol these values and encourage involvement of students from all backgrounds and degrees. I personally loved the work dynamic. People got things done, but there was a sense of joy and satisfaction in their work.
cons: The campus ministry office gets really busy during religious holidays.

review_title: Great place to be a student; as staff, pay is mediocre but excellent benefits
job_title: Program Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Enriched educational environment, beautiful campus.  Healthcare coverage with low out of pocket. Covered parking (annual fee).
cons: Raises are small even for highly productive people.  No clear path for advancement for staff in academic departments.

review_title: fabulous paid internship experience at the Santa Clara Magazine
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: positive work environment, beautiful location, institution upholds high ethical standards, i got a lot of hands-on experience, met wonderful people and made great connections. all around the best work experience ive ever had, out of 7 jobs
cons: they use Groupwise for their email client, which many people find frustrating, not user friendly, and out of date. Raiser's Edge is another program used internally that is tedious and not very efficient, slowing you down and wasting valuable work time

job_title: Assistant Director in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Very close-knit campus community, and not in an annoying or suffocating way - in a genuinely friendly and cooperative way.

Great benefits.

Good work-life balance.

A very positive and cheerful place to work, with a strong sense of mission.

Universities can be notorious for poor internal communication and a lot of bureaucracy, but SCU is actually managed fairly well and it felt like morale was always good.
cons:
Salaries are low.

Transportation and transit perks/benefits could be stronger.

If you're not Catholic, you can sometimes feel a little bit isolated from parts of the campus community.

job_title: Lifeguard in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Flexible hours, great weather (aside from winter quarter), fun staff, and solid hourly pay. You can also get a lot of studying and homework done during shifts, which is a nice perk for students. This is an ideal on-campus job for students looking to make good money in a stress-free environment!
cons: The opening shift can be brutal thanks to the undesirable task of removing tarps from the pool. Winter gets awfully cold, but that's honestly the only downside to the job.

job_title: Student Research Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Super positive staff and coworkers. Everyone believes wholeheartedly in the causes that FAI puts time and energy into every day. Great food and gatherings.
cons: The office does not have good natural light. The pay is pretty marginal for the amount of work that goes into the research (which is the meat and veggies of the institute).

job_title: Business Development Representative in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Working for the SCU Dev office was one of the most beneficial and valuable growing experiences I've ever had. Worked with a staff who fully supported me and provided and wonderful team atmosphere. The leadership from Casey Lerner was fantastic.
cons: I have no negative criticism. I would recommend the option to work at the Development Office to anyone.

job_title: Accounting Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Flexible and Friendly. They really work around student schedules and accommodate for exams. Management is very helpful and happy to answer any questions which is beneficial when training in  a new position.
cons: Work environment was great but it was somewhat monotonous and low-energy. Very routine but varies by department.

review_title: Nice place to work, staff salaries low
job_title: Administrative Associate in San Jose, CA
pros: Very pleasant culture, nice people, great co-workers and camaraderie.
cons:
The pay for non-executive staff is too low given the cost of living. Even with good benefits, the pay is still too low. 

People come to SCU and don't leave, so the internal promotion opportunities are severely limited.

My last manager was a horrible micro-manager... she made me miserable for three years.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Fun to interact with students, run experiments. Hands off approach to TAs lets you set your own schedule, though it always has to fit in with the undergrads.
cons: Grading way too many lab reports and homework assignments. Most students do the minimum and barely show up to extra help. Expect many copied homeworks and very little feedback from students.

job_title: Media Services in Santa Clara, CA
pros: It is good pay for a student job.  Most of the work is really easy.  It is really hard to get fired.
cons: The job can be boring.  There are some weirdos that work there.  You will never be praised for your work no matter how hard you try.

review_title: Was an excellent part time job which provided me with pocket cash throughout my college career
job_title: Office Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Really flexible hours.
Focus on productivity.
Understanding and accepting environment.
Positions available for international students.
Great working with fellow classmates.
Also, if you get a full time staff position, your offspring can attend the school for free.
cons: Most of the tasks were pretty menial. They are highly repetitious also. As can be expected with most on campus student jobs, there was little to no room for advancement.

job_title: Business Development Representative in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: He always provided a healthy and uplifting atmosphere for the students to work in. Held the students well being as his top interest and truly cared about what he was doing for the University.
cons: He could probably put more emphasis on the work life balance for students. There are so many other commitments that college students have other than their part time job and there needs to be a greater understanding of that.

job_title: Research Fellowship in San Jose, CA
pros: I loved the work I did. My supervisor was friendly and helpful and provided me with valuable professional experience. I would work with him again.
cons: They were awful about getting my payment account set up. I had to interact multiple times with human resources and was not paid for the first two months.

job_title: Office Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: As a student, it is important to me that I establish as many ties as possible during my attendance at SCU.
cons: My time working at Santa Clara University has been overwhelmingly positive and I would recommend it to anyone.

job_title: Research Assistant in San Bruno, CA
pros: Great campus, great resources, great coworkers. The school and supervisors are generally very flexible about schedules and are willing to accommodate student employee schedules.
cons: The wages for student employees are pretty low. If it weren't for the flexibility in work schedules, I would have sought employment off campus.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The office had flexible schedules, nice accommodating people, easy to get to location. Manager was very nice and easy to work with.
cons: Had some heavy lifting in terms of warehouse and storage areas.  Often working for multiple people resulting in some communication discrepancies.  Co-workers often on business trips.

review_title: Decent place to gain some experience but not a good place for someone looking to stay somewhere for some time
job_title: Intern in Santa Clara, CA
pros: People are generally very easy to work and are always eager to help others. Very good work/life balance and benefits
cons: Opportunities for upward mobility are generally pretty hard to come by and most managers or directors have generally been there awhile

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Very motivated and bright students which make working there as an adjunct professor a real joy.  A majority of students have good work experience in Silicon Valley companies.  The campus is very beautiful and staff is extremely helpful.  Very nice place to work.
cons: The pay is pretty minimal.  In addition, the campus is extremely liberal and not what I would consider as holding "Catholic" values.

job_title: Research Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Great faculty and staff that are highly educated, experienced, and excited to help.
- Beautiful campus
cons:
- Some of the research labs are small, making it difficult to have large lab groups
- Can use better placement opportunities for some fields

review_title: Good place to balance school work and work
job_title: Library Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Friendly Staff, Chill environment and work schedules are extremely flexible. It's cool that you can have some time to do your homework during the job.
cons: Working in a school environment is great but you get babied a lot with a lot of room for error compared to the outside world. Work is sometimes boring during the slow hours in the library

job_title: Employer Relations Program Coordinator in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I've been a student employee at SCU for the past three years and don't have enough wonderful things to say about my experience! I currently work in Employer Relations at the Career Center. Their staff is friendly, warm, and understanding.
cons: Student Assistant work can sometimes be monotonous and boring.

job_title: Tutor in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Very flexible with hours for students, easy to get shift changed
cons: Very bad pay for tutoring.  I know it's through the school but $9.50 for a job that is worth around $20 at least is just not cutting it.  Especially when much easier jobs get paid around the same amount as tutors.

job_title: Campus Safety in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Beautiful campus. nice cafeteria food.
cons: Back stabbing environment, supervisor stated so. Supervisor positions are elected, thus good old boy network. Many supervisors are very incompetent and given jobs by age. Truly very discriminative environment. Staff has low wages, bucks go to professors and directors. Many OSHA violations. Do as I say culture, policies are not readily available. keep looking!

job_title: HUB Writing Partner in Santa Clara, CA
pros: It's great interacting with people on the regular, and being of service to them. A fun and stimulating work environment to come in to.
cons: This is the best student job on campus, so there are few cons to the position. Wage could be increased for students who have worked there for multiple years.

job_title: Office Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Flexible schedule. Interesting people to work with. Beautiful networking opportunities if you work in a department you don't usually interact with. For example, might benefit to work in a business department as an English major. Cool.
cons: Downsides...hmmm, not many. Maybe feeling like they're a little phoney about being sustainable. So much paper waste even though they're supposedly so green. Kind of a bummer.

job_title: Transportation Services Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Work with talented individuals who share a common vision of competence, conscience, and compassion. Amazing opportunities to work within the community and give service to others.
cons: Often rude customers that come in wanting you to make exceptions for them, but this is a great way to improve customer service skills. This job definitely tests your patience and your organization skills.

job_title: Student Grader in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good to work. I loved working there. The best part is that as a student grader you have flexibility to work according to your suitable timings.
cons: Nothing bad at that level. Yeah but salary is not that great but you can do more than one job if you want there is no harm in working as grader.

review_title: Fine university, fine place to work
job_title: Coaching Staff in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The school has a strong commitment to its students. The school also creates an excellent environment for collegial, academic work.
cons: The development and alumni offices are too far away from the main campus and this can at times be problematic.

job_title: Director in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Friendly, flexible, retirement benefits, beautiful campus
cons: Under paid, no bonus structure, little professional development and ability to grow, low morale

review_title: Katharine and George Alexander Community Law Center
job_title: Law Clerk/Student Intern in San Jose, CA
pros:
You get to help those who are in need and do not have the means to hire counsel.  

The supervising attorneys give good guidance on what is necessary to be successful.  

Great experience.
cons: There are limited number of parking spots in front of the Law Center.

job_title: IT At Santa Clara University School of Law in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Very interesting mix of people and everyone gets along well. Its a tight knit group and a great place to work.
cons: Frankly, none. Things run smoothly, the work is always taken care of it and most people seem happy.

job_title: IT Technician in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Most of the employees and students are very friendly, and very loyal to the school. It was a fun place to work. Also the school gym is a huge plus.
cons: There is a lot of red tape and official procedures that limit creativity in solving problems. Some of the work is repetitive.

job_title: Student Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Very flexible
- Very understanding
- A family oriented outfit
- More than willing to teach you the skills you need to succeed
cons:
- The hours can be a bit random.
- The compensation could be a little better.
- The meetings can be a bit of a time waster.

job_title: Assistant Director in Santa Clara, CA
pros: SCU provides staff with a community to call home, rather than just a place to work. People really do care about one another.
cons: Salary and growth potential. Salaries are low compared to those available in Silicon Valley and there is very little growth, if any at all.

review_title: Great Place ... Students, Faculty and Staff are focused on the right things
job_title: in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Terrific students ... dedicated and capable
Wonderful sharing and collegial atmosphere
Great faculty and staff
cons: there is really not much.  It is a terrific place and I love being part of the team.

review_title: Very good opportunities for student employment.
job_title: Benson Infor Desk in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Flexible scheduling, can work around class and other activities. It's a great place to go to college with San Francisco less than an hour away.  They Bay area also has a ton of opportunities for post-graduation.
cons: The jobs for students can sometimes not be engaging.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
good programs and support on the graduate level engineering
good quality research and academic advising
small class sizes if enrolling
good benefits and great people
cons: HR seemed to be a little disorganized and unable to meet min requirements to support the employees. The were helpful when then could be but  "requires improvement"

job_title: Community Facilitator in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
-Learn how to organize events
-Interact with
-Learn how to deal with people
-Learn leaderships values
-
cons:
-Ineffective communication between superiors and inferiors
-Loss of personal not because of time constraints, but because of behavior restriction

review_title: It was great! Definitely a place you would want to come and work on a daily basis. Highly recommended.
job_title: Tutor in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Friendly environment. Great people to work with. A very supportive community to surround yourself with. Awesome place to be.
cons: There really weren't any I can think of.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
-- The best perks for a student: free tuition and getting paid on top of that!
-- Get to mentor some of the brightest students in the Bay.
cons: -- Not much in the way of overtime but considering the perks, it doesn't really matter

review_title: Excellent place to work if you are not the primary bread winner for your family.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Wonderful colleagues, great support from the university community, family-friendly, excellent university, outstanding students and programs.
cons: Low pay for Silicon Valley, not a lot of room for advancement.

review_title: part-time student job at The Housing Department
job_title: Business Service Specialist in Santa Clara, CA
pros: great hours, very flexible, staff is extremely friendly and always willing to help.
cons: the shift after housing registration can be very demanding. Fortunately, the staff has identified this issue and more students are scheduled around this time.

job_title: Information Technology Technical Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Worked as a student worker in the Business School.  I was paid well and treated well and it was a great learning opportunity.  My manager was totally decent.
cons: Scheduling around finals could be problematic.

job_title: Student Research Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Not bad on the pay scale, and got to work with an awesome professor.
cons: It really depends on who you work for. Some professors provide great practical experience while some are really only looking for folks to do their citations.

job_title: Student Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: I had a great experience working for Santa Clara University.  Each department is well connect to one another, which made communication between departments seamless.
cons: I wish they paid more. But other than that it was a pretty good experience.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great place to learn new things. Awesome school with lots of facilities. Staff and faculty members are helpful
cons: No such downside as such. Never faced any while working here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great bosses. Learned at a lot.
cons: Sometimes I wonder if I could have been pushed a little more to more proactive. With maybe just a tap on the shoulder.

review_title: Engineering School at the heart of Engineering's Top Companies
job_title: Lecturer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: A values-driven employer with a social conscience
cons: Lots of change in management in recent years.  Many forms of subtle discrimination against women and minorities.

review_title: One of the best employers I've ever had
job_title: Student Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Flexible schedule/shift
Workload usually not so heavy
Opportunity to participate in different types of projects
Great place for expanding your network, possibly help career after graduation
cons: can't think of one, I love working for SCU

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Safe campus, young vibe, working for students, benefits are pretty cool, opportunities to attend many on campus events, great work environment
cons: Hard to meet people outside your department, expensive dining options, small campus, could use better management

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Research was really interesting. In my case, my mentor was really engaged with the project and there were good discussions that lead to quality results.
cons: As a student, the maximum working hours per week should not exceed 19.

job_title: Student Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Flexible hours to fit your schedule as a student
- Supportive supervisors who want to see you succeed
- As a student, convenience working on-campus
cons: - Limitations to promotion because of student employee status

job_title: Assistant Director in Santa Clara, CA
pros: SCU automatically contributes 10% of your salary to your 401k.  Fantastic colleagues.  Meaningful work.
cons: Pay is lower than industry standards.  It’s a hard balance for all of us to consider working at SCU long-term.

review_title: It is a pleasure to work for SCU
job_title: Employer Relations Administrator in Santa Clara, CA
pros: SCU offers exceptional benefits to it's employees and the open Jesuit and social justice values are strong.
cons: I don't have any cons at this time.

review_title: Excellent work environment. Great colleagues, great students. A place to grow.
job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The University provides on-site professional development opportunities. A Tech center and new multimedia classrooms. Accessible via public transportation. Academic environment.
cons: Can't think of any cons.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: It lives up to being the #2 school in the west.
cons: The cost of living is too much considering the pay scale.

job_title: Professor in Houston, TX
pros: I feel will be an Excellent place to work!
cons:
What can be said prematurely about a place of business you have not experienced
yet, but no comment

job_title: Lab Monitor in Santa Clara, CA
pros: You have a lot of free time while working as a lab monitor.
cons: salary is not that high.

review_title: Graduate Student (Masters in Computer Science & Engineering)
job_title: Graduate Student in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good Study Environment, Clean surroundings and astounding location
cons: Expensive in all departments including university clothing line, stationaries and even dining services.

review_title: Good University with balanced culture and work life
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Amazing professor having lots of experience in various industry.
cons: Number of Units are too high and costly

review_title: Great place to work while in school
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Flexibility 
They understand students' hectic schedules
Administration is very nice
cons: The pay is very low for student workers.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Tuition paid for, Hourly wage, fascinating work environment, valid experience for job market
cons: Tough to get a research position, need to put in a lot of time to be considered.

review_title: Campus focused on the success of their students
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Friendly staff and faculty with a great culture of helping educate the minds of future students.
cons: Did not have any difficulties with the campus..

job_title: Research Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Really fun! We worked on crime data, and this was done within the Mathematics and CS department. Research here is worth it.
cons: I don't have anything negative to say.

job_title: in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I worked at SCU as a TA.  The professor in charge of TAs was very nice.
cons: Actually, I don't think of any cons working at SCU right now.

job_title: Head Desk Receptionist in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Flexible hours, healthy and functioning work environment, and convenient work locations.
cons: Some employees wish they could work more hours, for some specific positions.

job_title: in Hayward, CA
pros: tuition remission, athletics facilities, pool etc
cons: new administrators have a different view on how to work, expectations not voiced

job_title: in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great part time job as an undergrad, easier to get letters of rec
cons: Much of the work is just busy work - is what TA's would normally do.

review_title: Great Place to find Student Work
job_title: Student Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Work with employers on what hours to work
Really flexible with allowing workers to call out for school-related assignments
cons: Can sometimes be really repetitive work

review_title: Run of the mill catering job
job_title: Caterer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good pay, fun people to work with
cons: Terrible scheduling management, overtime is 1.5X but can sometimes be 6  hours over regular shift.

job_title: Receptionist in Santa Clara, CA
pros: It was a easy job; I was allowed to do homework when it was slow.
cons: The job didn't pay much which was expected since I was just a receptionist.

job_title: Associate in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great work environment and friendly people.
cons: Very formal and conservative ideology. Try best to be innovative and practical at the same time.

job_title: Student Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great work life balance. The staff and faculty are like a community.
cons: Not really much to say. I really enjoyed my job these past four years.

review_title: Good or Bad Depending on Who You Research For
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: You typically choose who you do research for based off of professor and interests.
cons: Low wages, but interesting work.

job_title: Operations Associate in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Education benefits, 401k match, value-driven commununity
cons: Unlivable wage, challenging to grow due to politics

job_title: Santa Clara University-Student in Santa Clara, CA
pros: very free environment to work and the boss is nice
cons: the hourly salary is low 9$/hour as a student worker

job_title: in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
-Supportive Team
-Flexible with school schedule
cons: Can't think of anything bad to think of working at the office.

job_title: Research Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: You are able to be learning as a student
cons: Not much that I can say, you get the best of both worlds

job_title: Student Grader in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Only ever had interaction with one supervisor, which was nice.
- Self reporting hours w/ easy to use software for reporting
cons: - Sometimes had payment errors

review_title: Great learning experience and foundation to launch off of
job_title: in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good working environment with flexibility
cons: Plenty of competition with little resources

job_title: Research Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Able to make my own hours around my class schedule
Boss is understanding of class comes before work
cons: Could have better communication within the department

job_title: Coordinator in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I really enjoyed the flexibility of the job and how I become more involved with the school.
cons: They pay was a little low

job_title: Student Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great opportunity for students. Flexible Schedule. Best Job On Campus.
cons: There are not too many downsides for working at the library.

review_title: Working as a student at SCU
job_title: Research Assistant/Tutor in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Lots of varying job opportunities, decent pay for students, flexibility with hours
cons: Some jobs definitely better than others

review_title: Excellent place to work , Everyone is nice to you
job_title: Conference Services in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good pay and accommodation for summer
cons: Not many  maybe more hours for summer.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Beautiful environment with people who want to succeed and make positive changes in the world
